applestock 0.1.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • An introduction of applestock

    Introduction

    Applestock is a data package about Apple’s stock price, which records information related to Apple’s stock price since 2007. This packet contains a total of two data sets and two functions. A data set called “adj.price_df” records the daily share price of Apple from 2007 to 2018, in the form of closing prices. At the same time, this data package also records information such as daily trading volume, dividends and so on. Another data packet, productreturn, is a composite data packet. The data of this dataset mainly comes from the adj.price_df dataset we mentioned earlier, which data is downloaded by using API provided by Intrinio, a financial data website. Another data source of productreturn is the wikipedia website, which records the time when all of Apple’s new mobile phone products and new IOS systems were released.

    installation

    To install this package, please input the code as follows:

    library(applestock)

    Instructions

    Packages

    To have a look of the stock price of Apple, write the code as follows:

    library(applestock)
applestock::adj.price_df

    To have a look of adj.price_df, write this code:

    head(applestock::adj.price_df)

    To have a look of our combined dataset: stock returns before and after apple new products launches, write this code:

    applestock::productreturn

    This is how it looks like:

    library(knitr)
kable(applestock::productreturn)

    Functions

    HPPR

    This function is used to calculate the return received from holding AAPL’s stock over a period of time and sell it. The return is simply based on the capital gains&loss from the price difference between buy and sell. day.buy is the day assumed to buy the stock, and day.sell is the day assumed to sell the stock. Theoratically, day.buy should be a day before the day.sell. But this function allows you to input a day.buy later than day.sell, then in this case, the function uses day.buy as the date for sell. Both day.buy and day.sell should be of character, with a “%d-%m-%Y” format.

    To use this function, code like follows:

    applestock::HPPR(day.buy = "21-09-2018", day.sell = "25-09-2018")

    TDRP

    This function is used to calculate the return received from holding AAPL’s stock given a certain holding period. It does not either ask you to know the specific day for sell given your buying day, the return or ask you to remember the buying day when you want to calculate the return after selling stocks. You just need to know one day, what we call the base day here, and the numbers of days (say, 1 week, 1 months, etc) before or after the base day. Then the function can help you to calculate the return. The return is simply based on the capital gains&loss from the price difference between buy and sell. Base.day input should be of character, with a “%d-%m-%Y” format, while trading.day, you just need to input a integer.

    To use this function, code like follows:

    applestock::TDPR(base.day = "21-09-2018", trading.day = 30)

    Vignette

    For reconsturct a package or function like things aforementioned, you can check vignette of this package. Should remind you that if you want to run the vignette, you definitely should apply for a key token from Intrinio: https://intrinio.com/ from their US Stock Price API.
